You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would tend to choose the option that provides me with the most consistent earnings over the long run. In this game, both R and B have the potential to yield 40$ or more if the opponent also chooses the same option. However, choosing R gives a significantly lower payoff (0$) when the opponent chooses B, while choosing B results in a smaller difference (5$) between the best-case scenario and worst-case scenario compared to choosing R.

In 75 rounds, even small differences can add up significantly. For example, if I choose R and my opponent chooses B just once, I would lose 35$, whereas if they choose R when I chose B, I would only lose 5$. Since it's unlikely that the opponent will always choose the same option as me in 75 rounds, it makes sense to minimize the loss in those instances where our choices don't align.

Given this analysis, I would tend to choose B more frequently since it minimizes the potential for a large loss. However, it would be rational to occasionally switch strategies (to R) to maximize the potential for the higher payoff of 45$ when the opponent chooses R as well. In practice, I might use a strategy like "tit-for-tat" where I initially choose B but switch to R if my opponent chooses R in the previous round.

So, my choice would be {B}, but with occasional switches to R based on the opponent's behavior.
